APAS.name: Apple___Apple_scab

default: Remove infected leaves and fruit.
Apply copper-based or Captan fungicide as per label instructions.
Improve air circulation with proper pruning.
humidity: Increase fungicide frequency during high humidity.
Avoid overhead irrigation to reduce leaf wetness.
pH: Maintain soil pH between 6.0 and 7.0; add lime if too acidic.
temperature: Ensure proper ventilation during warm, moist periods.
fertilizer: Use balanced fertilizer to maintain plant vigor.
pesticide: Consider organic options (e.g., neem oil) if chemical options are not preferred.

sources: https://www.apsnet.org/edcenter/disandpath/fungalasco/pdlessons/Pages/AppleScab.aspx
Local Extension Service Guidelines

APBR.name: Apple___Black_rot

default: Remove and destroy infected tissues.
Apply copper-based fungicides.
humidity: Improve air circulation and minimize prolonged leaf wetness.
temperature: Reduce irrigation during warm weather to limit fungal growth.
fertilizer: Provide balanced nutrition to enhance tree health.
pesticide: Follow integrated pest management (IPM) guidelines for fungicide use.

sources: University of California Agriculture and Natural Resources
Extension Service Recommendations

APCR.name: Apple___Cedar_apple_rust

default: Prune and remove rusted leaves promptly.
Apply rust-specific fungicides (e.g., myclobutanil).
humidity: Thin the canopy to improve airflow and reduce humidity.
temperature: Avoid over-irrigation in warm weather to prevent prolonged wetness.
fertilizer: Use balanced fertilizer to promote vigorous growth.
pesticide: Apply copper-based fungicides if rust pressure is high.

sources: APSnet Citrus and Pome Fruit Disease Management
Extension guidelines

APHE.name: Apple___healthy

default: Maintain standard orchard management practices including pruning, proper irrigation, and balanced fertilization.
humidity: Ensure good canopy ventilation to reduce disease risk.
pH: Keep soil pH within 6.0 to 7.0 for optimal nutrient uptake.
temperature: Monitor irrigation during extreme temperatures.
fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer as recommended by soil tests.
pesticide: Use preventive sprays only if pest pressure increases.

sources: Local Extension Service
University Orchard Management Guidelines

BLHE.name: Blueberry___healthy

default: Maintain proper mulching, pruning, and balanced fertilization.
Ensure adequate drainage to prevent root diseases.
humidity: Avoid waterlogging; blueberries need well-drained, moist (not wet) soils.
pH: Blueberries require acidic soil (pH 4.5â€“5.5); adjust with elemental sulfur if needed.
temperature: Provide partial shade during extreme heat.
fertilizer: Use acidifying fertilizers formulated for blueberries.
pesticide: Monitor for pests and use organic pesticides if required.

sources: University of Georgia Blueberry Production Guide
Extension Service Blueberry Management

CHPM.name: Cherry___Powdery_mildew

default: Remove infected foliage promptly.
Apply sulfur-based or neem oil fungicides.
humidity: Increase fungicide frequency during high humidity and improve air circulation.
temperature: Fungicide applications are critical during warm, dry spells.
fertilizer: Ensure balanced fertilization to reduce plant stress.
pesticide: Follow label recommendations for fungicide application.

sources: Cherry Powdery Mildew Management - Extension Service
Research Review: Powdery Mildew Control in Fruit Trees

CHHE.name: Cherry___healthy

default: Maintain regular cultural practices including proper pruning, irrigation, and fertilization.
humidity: Ensure adequate air flow to minimize fungal pressure.
temperature: Protect trees from extreme temperature swings.
fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer as needed.
pesticide: Use preventive organic sprays if necessary.

sources: Cherry Orchard Management Guidelines - Extension

CCGL.name: Corn___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray_leaf_spot

default: Remove and destroy infected leaves.
Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil.
humidity: Adjust irrigation to avoid excessive moisture.
temperature: Avoid overwatering during warm weather.
fertilizer: Use balanced fertilizer to support plant health.
pesticide: Follow local extension service recommendations for fungicide treatments.

sources: Corn Disease Management - Extension Service
Research Article on Cercospora Leaf Spot Control

CCOR.name: Corn___Common_rust

default: Remove infected plant parts promptly.
Apply rust-specific fungicides (e.g., azoxystrobin).
humidity: Improve air flow and avoid overhead watering.
temperature: Reduce irrigation during warm periods.
fertilizer: Ensure balanced nutrition to reduce stress.
pesticide: Follow IPM guidelines for fungicide application.

sources: Corn Rust Management - Extension Service
Agricultural Research on Rust in Corn

CNLB.name: Corn___Northern_Leaf_Blight

default: Remove and destroy affected leaves.
Apply fungicides such as azoxystrobin.
humidity: Thin the canopy to enhance air circulation.
temperature: Avoid prolonged leaf wetness by adjusting irrigation.
fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer to support plant vigor.
pesticide: Adhere to local guidelines for fungicide applications.

sources: Northern Leaf Blight Management - Extension Service

CNHE.name: Corn___healthy

default: Continue standard agronomic practices including balanced fertilization, proper irrigation, and routine pest monitoring.
humidity: Ensure proper drainage and avoid overwatering.
temperature: Adjust irrigation during extreme heat.
fertilizer: Use a balanced fertilizer based on soil test recommendations.
pesticide: Apply preventive IPM measures if needed.

sources: Standard Agronomic Practices for Corn - Extension Service

GRBR.name: Grape___Black_rot

default: Remove infected clusters and leaves immediately.
Apply fungicides such as mancozeb or myclobutanil.
humidity: Increase canopy ventilation to lower humidity.
temperature: Control irrigation during warm, humid periods.
fertilizer: Use balanced fertilization to support vine health.
pesticide: Follow recommendations from grape disease management literature.

sources: Grape Disease Management - Extension Service
Research on Black Rot in Grapes

GRES.name: Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles)

default: Prune out affected vines and remove infected debris.
Apply copper-based fungicides.
humidity: Improve air circulation in the vineyard.
temperature: Avoid waterlogging and maintain moderate conditions.
fertilizer: Ensure balanced nutrients for vine health.
pesticide: Use integrated disease management practices.

sources: Grape Esca Management - Extension Service

GRLB.name: Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spot)

default: Remove infected leaves and improve sanitation.
Apply fungicides such as myclobutanil.
humidity: Increase airflow to reduce prolonged leaf wetness.
temperature: Adjust irrigation to avoid excessive moisture.
fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer to enhance vine health.
pesticide: Follow local recommendations for fungicide usage.

sources: Grape Leaf Blight Management - Extension Service

GRHE.name: Grape___healthy

default: Maintain regular vineyard management including pruning, balanced fertilization, and pest monitoring.
humidity: Ensure good air circulation.
temperature: Monitor irrigation during temperature extremes.
fertilizer: Follow soil test recommendations for nutrient application.
pesticide: Apply preventive measures if pest pressure increases.

sources: Grape Vineyard Management Guidelines

ORHL.name: Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening)

default: Remove severely infected trees.
Implement strict vector control to manage psyllids.
humidity: Avoid excessive moisture which can boost psyllid populations.
temperature: Use reflective mulches and optimized irrigation to regulate canopy temperature.
fertilizer: Apply balanced citrus fertilizers.
pesticide: Use insecticides targeting psyllids, following integrated pest management protocols.

sources: Citrus Greening Management - USDA Extension
Research on Haunglongbing Control

PCBS.name: Peach___Bacterial_spot

default: Remove infected tissues and improve sanitation.
Apply copper-based bactericides.
humidity: Avoid overhead irrigation to reduce leaf wetness.
temperature: Bacterial spot worsens in warm, moist conditions; adjust watering accordingly.
fertilizer: Use balanced fertilizer to support plant health.
pesticide: Follow local extension guidelines for bactericide application.

sources: Peach Disease Management - Extension Service

PCHE.name: Peach___healthy

default: Maintain standard orchard practices: proper irrigation, pruning, and balanced fertilization.
humidity: Ensure proper spacing and air circulation.
temperature: Monitor during extreme weather conditions.
fertilizer: Apply fertilizers based on soil test recommendations.
pesticide: Use preventive measures if pest pressure increases.

sources: Orchard Management Guidelines - Extension Service

PBBP.name: Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot

default: Remove infected leaves immediately.
Apply copper-based bactericides.
humidity: Avoid overhead watering to minimize moisture on foliage.
temperature: Keep conditions moderate to reduce stress.
fertilizer: Ensure balanced nutrient supply.
pesticide: Follow IPM guidelines for bactericide application.

sources: Pepper Disease Management - Extension Service

PBHE.name: Pepper,_bell___healthy

default: Maintain standard cultural practices, including proper irrigation, fertilization, and pruning.
humidity: Ensure good ventilation to reduce disease risk.
temperature: Monitor and adjust watering during heat waves.
fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer based on crop needs.
pesticide: Implement preventive pest management if necessary.

sources: Bell Pepper Production Guidelines - Extension Service

PTEB.name: Potato___Early_blight

default: Remove infected leaves and haul away plant debris.
Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb.
humidity: Improve field drainage and reduce excessive moisture.
temperature: Early blight is favored by warm, humid conditions; adjust irrigation accordingly.
fertilizer: Use balanced fertilizer to boost plant resilience.
pesticide: Follow local fungicide schedules.

sources: Potato Early Blight Management - Extension Service
Research on Early Blight Control

PTLB.name: Potato___Late_blight

default: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately.
Apply late blight fungicides such as metalaxyl promptly.
humidity: Ensure proper drainage and avoid overhead irrigation.
temperature: Late blight thrives in cool, wet conditions; consider protective measures.
fertilizer: Maintain balanced nutrition to minimize stress.
pesticide: Strictly follow fungicide application schedules.

sources: Potato Late Blight Management - Extension Service

PTHE.name: Potato___healthy

default: Continue standard agronomic practices including proper irrigation, balanced fertilization, and pest monitoring.
humidity: Avoid waterlogging.
temperature: Monitor irrigation during extreme heat.
fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer as per soil tests.
pesticide: Use preventive pest management if required.

sources: Standard Potato Crop Management - Extension Service

RAHE.name: Raspberry___healthy

default: Maintain routine care including pruning, mulching, and balanced fertilization.
humidity: Ensure proper air circulation to minimize fungal diseases.
temperature: Protect from extreme temperature fluctuations.
fertilizer: Use fertilizers formulated for berry crops.
pesticide: Apply organic pest control if needed.

sources: Raspberry Crop Management - Extension Service

SOHE.name: Soybean___healthy

default: Follow routine agronomic practices with balanced nitrogen management and regular fertilization.
humidity: Avoid waterlogged conditions.
temperature: Monitor during temperature extremes.
fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer and consider nitrogen fixers.
pesticide: Implement integrated pest management (IPM) strategies.

sources: Soybean Production Guidelines - Extension Service

SQPM.name: Squash___Powdery_mildew

default: Remove infected leaves and improve air circulation.
Apply sulfur or potassium bicarbonate fungicides.
humidity: Avoid high humidity by adjusting irrigation.
temperature: Powdery mildew often occurs in warm, dry conditions; timely fungicide application is key.
fertilizer: Ensure balanced nutrition to minimize plant stress.
pesticide: Use organic fungicides if possible.

sources: Squash Powdery Mildew Control - Extension Service
Research on Powdery Mildew in Cucurbits

STLS.name: Strawberry___Leaf_scorch

default: Remove scorched leaves and improve field sanitation.
Apply recommended fungicides for leaf scorch.
humidity: Reduce excessive moisture by adjusting irrigation.
pH: Maintain soil pH between 5.5 and 6.5 for strawberries.
temperature: Avoid prolonged high temperatures which can exacerbate leaf scorch.
fertilizer: Use low-nitrogen fertilizer to prevent excessive vegetative growth.
pesticide: Apply organic fungicides if necessary.

sources: Strawberry Production Manual - Extension Service

STHE.name: Strawberry___healthy

default: Maintain routine care including proper irrigation, mulching, and balanced fertilization.
humidity: Ensure good air circulation to reduce disease risk.
temperature: Protect plants from extreme heat or cold.
fertilizer: Apply fertilizers formulated for berry crops.
pesticide: Monitor pest populations and use organic controls as needed.

sources: Strawberry Crop Management - Extension Service

TMBS.name: Tomato___Bacterial_spot

default: Remove infected foliage and fruit.
Apply copper-based bactericides.
humidity: Avoid overhead watering to minimize leaf wetness.
temperature: Adjust watering in warm, humid conditions to limit bacterial proliferation.
fertilizer: Use balanced fertilizer to promote healthy growth.
pesticide: Follow IPM guidelines for bactericide applications.

sources: Tomato Bacterial Spot Management - Extension Service

TMEB.name: Tomato___Early_blight

default: Remove infected leaves immediately.
Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb.
humidity: Water at the base to reduce leaf wetness.
temperature: Early blight is favored by warm, humid conditions; adjust irrigation accordingly.
fertilizer: Provide balanced fertilizer to avoid plant stress.
pesticide: Apply fungicides as per local guidelines.

sources: Tomato Early Blight Management - Extension Service

TMLB.name: Tomato___Late_blight

default: Remove and destroy infected plants.
Apply late blight fungicides such as metalaxyl promptly.
humidity: Ensure proper drainage and avoid overhead irrigation.
temperature: Late blight thrives in cool, wet conditions; consider protective measures.
fertilizer: Maintain balanced nutrition to reduce stress.
pesticide: Follow strict fungicide application schedules.

sources: Tomato Late Blight Management - Extension Service

TMLM.name: Tomato___Leaf_Mold

default: Remove infected foliage.
Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil.
humidity: Improve air circulation to help dry the foliage.
temperature: Leaf mold is common in cool, damp conditions; adjust irrigation accordingly.
fertilizer: Use balanced fertilizer to support plant resilience.
pesticide: Follow local fungicide recommendations.

sources: Tomato Leaf Mold Control - Extension Service

TMSL.name: Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot

default: Remove infected leaves and debris.
Apply fungicides targeted at Septoria leaf spot.
humidity: Enhance air flow and minimize moisture.
temperature: Monitor irrigation during high temperatures.
fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer to reduce plant stress.
pesticide: Follow extension service guidelines for fungicide application.

sources: Tomato Septoria Leaf Spot Management - Extension Service

TMSM.name: Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider_mite

default: Regularly inspect and remove mite-infested foliage.
Apply miticides or introduce biological control agents.
humidity: Maintain moderate humidity as spider mites thrive in dry conditions.
pH: Overall plant health is key; soil pH is less critical here.
temperature: High temperatures can increase mite populations; monitor closely.
fertilizer: Avoid excessive nitrogen, which can promote mite growth.
pesticide: Use targeted miticides or biological agents as needed.

sources: Tomato Spider Mite Control - Extension Service
Research on Mite Management in Tomatoes

TMTS.name: Tomato___Target_Spot

default: Remove infected leaves promptly.
Apply fungicides specific for target spot.
humidity: Manage irrigation to reduce leaf wetness.
temperature: Improve air circulation to reduce humidity around the plant.
fertilizer: Use balanced fertilizer to support plant health.
pesticide: Follow integrated pest management practices.

sources: Tomato Target Spot Management - Extension Service

TMYC.name: Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus

default: Remove heavily infected plants.
Control whitefly populations using insecticides.
humidity: Manage greenhouse humidity to reduce vector populations.
temperature: Avoid excessive heat to reduce plant stress and vector activity.
fertilizer: Use balanced nutrition to boost plant immunity.
pesticide: Apply insecticides targeting whiteflies following IPM strategies.

sources: Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus Management - Extension Service
Research on Whitefly Control in Tomatoes

TMMV.name: Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus

default: Remove and destroy infected plants.
Sanitize tools and use virus-free transplants.
humidity: Maintain moderate humidity to avoid stress.
temperature: Maintain optimal growing temperatures to support plant immunity.
fertilizer: Apply balanced fertilizer to ensure robust growth.
pesticide: No direct chemical treatment; focus on cultural practices.

sources: Tomato Mosaic Virus Management - Extension Service

TMHE.name: Tomato___healthy

default: Maintain standard cultural practices: proper watering, balanced fertilization, and routine pruning.
humidity: Ensure adequate air circulation.
pH: Keep soil pH within the optimal range (6.0 to 6.8).
temperature: Monitor and adjust irrigation during extreme temperatures.
fertilizer: Apply fertilizers based on soil test results.
pesticide: Use preventive measures only if pest pressure increases.

sources: Tomato Crop Management - Extension Service
